thread.title: America’s Most Unlikely Energy Project Is Rising From a Louisiana Bayou
thread.title_full: America’s Most Unlikely Energy Project Is Rising From a Louisiana Bayou

title: America’s Most Unlikely Energy Project Is Rising From a Louisiana Bayou
text:
03 America’s Most Unlikely Energy Project Is Rising From a Louisiana Bayou 
Bloomberg: From a mile away, at the distant end of a flat, two-lane road, the Sabine Pass Liquefied Natural Gas terminal materializes like an alien city from the haze of the Louisiana bayou. Five white cylinders with domed tops, each 140 feet tall and 225 feet in diameter, rise from the empty horizon. Set on the Texas border 4 miles from the mouth of the Sabine River on the Gulf Coast, the terminal is one of the largest industrial energy facilities under construction in North America. The domes, made of nickel alloy and wrapped in a layer of carbon steel, are essentially giant freezers, each capable of holding 81,000 tons of liquefied natural gas (LNG) at -260F.
